page.title: 12ABERLADY - The Gardens
page.content: Connected with the Carmellite Priory in Luffness, but at a suitable distance off, was a nunnery, the walled garden of which is situated at the extreme east end of the village, down the little hill known as Smiddy Brae where, until just after the 1939-45 war, the village blacksmith's forge was in operation. In this nunnery garden thirteen modern houses were erected some seven years ago, in an exclusive development. In the retaining north wall are still to be seen the apertures or "skeps" for the beehives, from which the nuns obtained the wax for making and selling candles. Aberlady and its vicinity is a scheduled Conservation Area and as such housing and other development is strictly controlled, which makes the Gardens development rather special.
